title: Billy Collins' poem 'Litany' is universally understood to be based on the first two lines of a poem by Jacques Crickillon. Where can one find the original poem by Crickillon? - Quora

response.answer_text: It is possible that this is a prank by Billy Collins, who is prone to such. It isn’t that it is “universally understood” to be based on those lines, it’s that Collins attributes the epigraph that begins his poem “Litany” to the Belgian artist and poet Jacques Crickillon, who would have written those lines, if he did, in French. Here’s what Collins writes: “You are the bread and the knifeThe crystal goblet and the wine…” — Jacques Crickillon A search through the Google ebook archive for Crickillon using the words “couteau” (knife) and “pain” (bread) yields the following from “Lettre à Lorna” Lui dire que la pierre, la fleur, le coquillage, le pain, le couteau, la barrière du jardin est Lorna (“tell him that the stone, the flower, the shell, the bread, the knife, the garden fence, is Lorna”) Perhaps someone more familiar with the works of Crickillon could chime in?
